Award.AwardTitle: Mineralized tissue research on the life history of Virunga mountain gorillas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The major objective of this project is to conduct a comprehensive analysis of dental and skeletal tissue microanatomy in a known population of African apes from the wild, Virunga mountain gorillas (Gorilla beringei beringei), Rwanda, with an emphasis on testing relationships between hard tissue development and specific environmental and life history factors. Using radiographic and histologic techniques, specific aims include : (1) generating primary data on dental and skeletal growth and development in mountain gorillas, establishing an important comparative foundation on great ape development in the wild, and test hypotheses concerning the influence of socioecological factors on variability in great ape life histories; (2) determining the presence and chronology of microanatomical features in hard tissues that record incidence of developmental stress (i.e., accentuated enamel striae; lines of arrested growth in bone); and (3) comparing these chronologies against climatic, behavioral and veterinary records to determine the manner in which environmental factors and characteristics of individual life histories (e.g., weaning, social status, disease, human disturbance) impact the growth of hard tissues and are recorded in their developing microanatomy. Given availability of associated life records, hard tissue research on Virunga mountain gorillas can contribute significant and unique insight into the biology and health of these critically-endangered great apes, and establish a framework based on the combined study of dental and skeletal tissues in well-documented natural populations that has significant transformative potential for the study of life history evolution from fossils.

Broader impacts of this project include new international collaborations that foster integration among scientific disciplines; creation of a digital archive of tooth and bone radiographic and microscopy images, available to Rwandan and US students and scientists; and research and training opportunities for US undergraduate and graduate students. Finally, support for a research assistant and additional training opportunities in Rwanda will build local expertise and capacity to ensure the long-term sustainability of mountain gorilla skeletal preservation and research efforts, and broaden participation of under-represented groups in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As modern humans, we are distinctive in our early weaning, slow childhood growth and late ages at first reproduction compared to great apes.  A central challenge in human origins research is to understand how, and in what social and ecological context, these unique features of our life history strategy evolved. Since fossils represent the only direct evidence for human life history evolution, an important focus has been on extracting developmental information from hard tissues such as bones and teeth. However, until recently, the comparative context for this work has been limited. Despite considerable diversity in the behavior, ecology and life histories of wild great apes, our knowledge of their physical development has overwhelmingly come from less well-documented museum samples or captivity. This project undertook the first comprehensive analysis of skeletal and dental development in a known population of wild great apes, mountain gorillas from Volcanoes National Park, Rwanda. Representing the most folivorous great ape population, Virunga mountain gorillas are especially important for understanding ecological influences on life history variation among our closest living relatives. Further, over 45 years of continuous observational study of recognized individuals from this population, first initiated by Dian Fossey, provides an unprecedented opportunity to directly test relationships between documented aspects of behavior, ecology and life history, and their proposed hard tissue proxies.

 

This research combined gross morphological studies of skeletal and dental remains with detailed investigations of their micro-anatomical structure, to generate important primary data on the physical growth and development of mountain gorillas. We tested the hypothesis that given their reliance on abundant and reliably available foods, mountain gorillas are accelerated in physical development, as they are in weaning age and first reproduction, compared to other great apes whose diets are more reliant on seasonally available foods.  Results demonstrated, for example, that despite having substantially larger adult endocranial volumes (a proxy for brain size), mountain gorillas reached adult brain size one year earlier than chimpanzees.  However, radiographic and histologic studies of dental development revealed a more complicated pattern. An important life history proxy in fossil studies, first permanent molar eruption by 3.2 years of age in Virunga mountain gorillas is broadly coincident with mean age at weaning. However, while they show similar ages at first molar eruption to chimpanzees, mountain gorillas initiate first molar calcification earlier during the prenatal period, thus allowing for an extended period over which to grow their substantially larger tooth crowns. In contrast, second permanent molar initiation is comparatively delayed in mountain gorillas, and the duration of molar root formation extended. These findings suggest that natural selection may have acted independently on first molar development (versus later dental development stages) in mountain gorillas, such that the emergence of this tooth is temporally linked to earlier ages at offspring independence, potentially to accommodate mechanical requirements for processing fibrous foods at weaning. We continue to investigate other developmental mechanisms (e.g., crown and root extension rates), which may contribute to these species differences. Finally, this research has also presented the unique opportunity to partner life records with morphological data from the same individuals, to investigate the manner in which adverse early life experiences impact inter-individual variability in skeletal-dental development.  Our results to date have shown that events such as poaching, injuries from conspecific aggression, and poor health are associated with developmental delays and/or defects in hard tissue formation. Together, these findings significantly advance our understanding of factors influencing variation in great ape development, including relationships between physical and behavioral developmental milestones, and they contribute an important foundation for contextualizing evidence bearing on the evolutionary origins of modern human life history. 

 

This research also contributed to establishing the world’s largest collection of mountain gorilla skeletal remains, an unparalleled resource that has generated student research training opportunities, facilitated international collaborations, and catalyzed new avenues of cross-disciplinary research at the intersection of evolutionary and conservation biology.  The Mountain Gorilla Skeletal Collection now represents 140 individuals, plus 65 other vertebrate specimens. Training and capacity building, through annual internships for Rwandan students and scientific staff, have developed expertise both to help support the long-term preservation of skeletal collections as scientific and educational resources in Rwanda, and to generate research.  Collection access has been openly extended to support mentored senior memoir research by three Rwandan undergraduate students, and to facilitate research opportunities for 14 U.S. undergraduate and graduate students, and senior scientists from local and international institutions. Representing the largest and longest-running observational study of wild gorillas, the collection provides unprecedented opportunities to integrate climatic datasets and behavioral, ecological and health data collected from living individuals, with data collected postmortem from their skeletons.  As the collection is projected to grow over time, so too will its value for supporting new cross-disciplinary research programs to address previously intractable questions about the evolutionary and conservation biology of these critically endangered great apes.
